tp:treatment-sec.title: Type species.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Acroriellus viridisquamosus Morrone and Ocampo, 1995.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Diagnosis.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Very small (2.5–3.8 mm); vestiture of seta-like scales and setae; elytra with small, rounded tubercles and series of three tubercles on interval 3.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Relationships.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Acroriellus is the sister genus to Acrostomus-Hyperoides. Originally, it was suggested that it was close to Acrorius (Morrone and Ocampo 1995).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Species included.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Acroriellus bobi Morrone and Ocampo, 1995; Acroriellus carinatus Morrone and Ocampo, 1995; Acroriellus similaris Morrone and Ocampo, 1995; Acroriellus tuberculosus Morrone and Ocampo, 1995; Acroriellus viridisquamosus Morrone and Ocampo, 1995; Acroriellus vittetae Morrone and Ocampo, 1995.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Geographical distribution.
tp:treatment-sec.p: South American Transition Zone (North Andean Paramo and Puna biogeographical provinces), in Colombia, Ecuador and Peru (Morrone and Ocampo 1995).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Material examined.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Acroriellus bobi (AMNH, CMNC), Acroriellus carinatus (CMNC), Acroriellus similaris (CMNC), Acroriellus tuberculosus (CMNC), Acroriellus viridisquamosus (CMNC, FMNH) and Acroriellus vittetae (AMNH, USNM).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Type species.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Acrorius puncticollis Kirsch, 1889 (by indication, monotypy).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Diagnosis.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Small (4.0–6.8 mm); vestiture of seta-like scales and setae; scape medium-sized (reaching eye when resting in scrobe); elytra with small, rounded tubercles.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Relationships.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Acrorius is the sister genus to Trachodema-Lamiarhinus-Philippius, taxa that in a previous analysis (Morrone 1997a) constituted a paraphyletic group.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Species included.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Acrorius andersoni Morrone, 1994; Acrorius bolivianus Ocampo and Morrone, 1996; Acrorius cuprinus Morrone, 1994; Acrorius nymphalis Morrone, 1994; Acrorius otramas Ocampo and Morrone, 1996; Acrorius papallacta Morrone, 1994; Acrorius pillahuata Morrone, 1994; Acrorius plicatifrons Morrone, 1994; Acrorius puncticollis Kirsch, 1889; Acrorius sisyphus Morrone, 1994.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Geographical distribution.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Bolivia, Ecuador and Peru (Morrone 1994a; Ocampo and Morrone 1996).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Material examined.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Acrorius andersoni (CMNC), Acrorius bolivianus (CMNC, MZFC), Acrorius cuprinus (CMNC), Acrorius nymphalis (CMNC), Acrorius otramas (CMNC), Acrorius papallacta (CMNC, MZFC), Acrorius pillahuata (CMNC, FMNH), Acrorius plicatifrons (FMNH) and Acrorius sisyphus (CNCI, CMNC).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Type species.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Adioristus bruchi Hustache, 1926 (by original designation).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Diagnosis.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Medium-sized (7.3–13.8 mm); integument black; vestiture of seta-like scales and setae; epistome raised; scrobal ventral tooth usually present; pronotum subquadrate.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Relationships.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Acrostomus is the sister genus to Hyperoides.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Species included.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Acrostomus bruchi (Hustache, 1926); Acrostomus cruralis Kuschel, 1958; Acrostomus foveicollis Kuschel, 1958; Acrostomus griseus (Guérin-Ménéville, 1839); Acrostomus magellanicus Kuschel, 1958; Acrostomus mordor Morrone, 1994; Acrostomus vianai Kuschel, 1958.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Host plants.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Acrostomus magellanicus and Acrostomus vianai: Azorella trifurcata (Gaertner) Pers., Bolax gummifera (Lam.) Spreng. and Mulinum spinosum (Cav.) Pers. (Apiaceae) (Morrone, 1994b).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Geographical distribution.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Andean region (Patagonian subregion), in southern Argentina and southern Chile (Morrone 1994b).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Material examined.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Acrostomus bruchi (CWOB, IPCN, MACN, MLP, MZFC), Acrostomus cruralis (MACN, USNM), Acrostomus foveicollis (CBPC, CWOB, MHNS, MZFC), Acrostomus griseus (CWOB, FIML, IPUM, MHNS, MLP, MZFC), Acrostomus magellanicus (BMNH, MHNS, USNM), Acrostomus mordor (AMNH, MACN, MLP, MZFC) and Acrostomus vianai (BMNH, MHNS).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Type species.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Antarctobius lacunosus Fairmaire, 1885 (subsequent designation by Morrone, 1992a).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Diagnosis.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Small to medium-sized (3.7–9.5 mm); vestiture of seta-like or subcircular scales and setae; pronotum subcircular; postocular lobes absent.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Relationships.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Antarctobius is closely related to Germainiellus, Listroderes and the clade Methypora-Rupanius-Acrorius-Trachodema-Lamiarhinus-Philippius. The distinction between Antarctobius, Germainiellus and Listroderes is not without doubt (see Morrone and Marvaldi, 1998), and future analyses may determine if they are merged into a single genus.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Species included.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Antarctobius abditus (Enderlein, 1907); Antarctobius bidentatus (Champion, 1918); Antarctobius falklandicus (Enderlein, 1907); Antarctobius germaini (Kolbe, 1907); Antarctobius hyadesii Fairmaire, 1885; Antarctobius lacunosus Fairmaire, 1885; Antarctobius malvinensis Posadas and Morrone, 2004; Antarctobius rugirostris Champion, 1918; Antarctobius vulsus (Enderlein, 1907); Antarctobius yefacel Morrone, 1992.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Host plants.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Antarctobius abditus: Senecio candidans DC (Asteraceae); Antarctobius hyadesii: Senecio alloeophyllus O. Hoffm. and Senecio candidans DC (Asteraceae) (Morrone, 1992a; Marvaldi, 1998).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Immature stages.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Antarctobius abditus and Antarctobius falklandicus (Marvaldi, 1998).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Geographical distribution.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Andean region (Subantarctic subregion), in southern Chile and southern Argentina, including the Falkland Islands (Islas Malvinas) (Morrone 1992a; Posadas and Morrone 2004; Posadas 2008, 2012).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Material examined.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Antarctobius abditus (BMNH), Antarctobius bidentatus (BMNH), Antarctobius falklandicus (AMPC, BMNH, MZFC), Antarctobius germaini (AMNH, BMNH, CADIC, CMNC, CWOB, IPUM, MHNS, MLP, MZFC), Antarctobius hyadesii (BPBM, CMNC, MHNS, MZFC), Antarctobius lacunosus (BMNH, MCZ, MHNS), Antarctobius rugirostris (BMNH), Antarctobius vulsus (BMNH, USNM) and Antarctobius yefacel (AMNH).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Type species.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Listroderes dentipennis Germain, 1895 (by original designation).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Diagnosis.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Small to medium-sized (6.0-8.4 mm); vestiture of seta-like scales and setae; pronotum transverse; postocular lobes present.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Relationships.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Germainiellus is closely related to Antarctobius, Listroderes and the clade Methypora-Rupanius-Acrorius-Trachodema-Lamiarhinus-Philippius. It was originally described as intermediate between Antarctobius and Listroderes (Morrone, 1993a). The distinction between Antarctobius, Germainiellus and Listroderes is not without doubt (see Morrone and Marvaldi, 1998), and future analyses may determine if they are merged into a single genus.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Species included.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Germainiellus angulipennis (Germain, 1895); Germainiellus attenuatus (Germain, 1895); Germainiellus dentipennis (Germain, 1895); Germainiellus fulvicornis (Germain, 1895); Germainiellus laevirostris (Germain, 1895); Germainiellus lugens (Germain, 1895); Germainiellus ovatus (Boheman, 1842); Germainiellus philippii (Germain, 1896); Germainiellus planipennis (Blanchard, 1851); Germainiellus punctiventris (Germain, 1895); Germainiellus rugipennis (Blanchard, 1851); Germainiellus salebrosus (Enderlein, 1907); Germainiellus spp. (MZFC).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Host plants.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Germainiellus dentipennis and Germainiellus fulvicornis: Nothofagus sp. (Nothofagaceae); Germainiellus laevirostris: Senecio smithii DC (Asteraceae); Germainiellus planipennis: Nothofagus dombeyi (Mirb.) Oerst. (Nothofagaceae) and Peumus boldus Mol. (Monimiaceae); Germainiellus salebrosus: Empetrum rubrum Vahl ex Willd. (Empetraceae) (Morrone, 1993a).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Geographical distribution.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Andean region (Subantarctic subregion), in southern Chile and southern Argentina, including the Falkland Islands (Islas Malvinas) (Morrone 1993a, 1994e; Posadas 2008, 2012).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Material examined.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Germainiellus angulipennis (MHNS), Germainiellus attenuatus (ARPC, MHNS), Germainiellus dentipennis (CBPC, CMNC, CWOB, MHNS, USNM), Germainiellus fulvicornis (AMNH, BPBM, CBCP, CMNC, CWOB, FIML, MCZ, MHNS, MLP, MZFC, USNM), Germainiellus laevirostris (BPBM, IPUM, MCZ, MHNS, MLP, USNM), Germainiellus lugens (CMNC, CWOB, IPUM, MACN, MCZ, MHNS, MZFC), Germainiellus ovatus (BMNH, MHNS, USNM), Germainiellus philippii (CMNC, DEI, MHNS, MZFC), Germainiellus planipennis (BMNH, CWOB, MHNS), Germainiellus punctiventris (MHNS), Germainiellus rugipennis (AMNH, BPBM, CADIC, CBCP, CMNC, MHNS, MLP, MZFC, USNM) and Germainiellus salebrosus (BMNH).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Type species.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Hyperoides fragariae Marshall, 1914 (by indication, monotypy).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Diagnosis.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Small to medium-sized (5.1–7.5 mm); vestiture of lanceolate scales and setae; postocular lobes present; elytra lacking anteapical tubercle.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Relationships.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Hyperoides is the sister genus to Acrostomus, contrasting with its more isolated position in a previous analysis (Morrone, 1997a).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Species included.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Hyperoides balfourbrownei (Kuschel, 1952); Hyperoides fragariae Marshall, 1914; Hyperoides murinus (Germain, 1896); Hyperoides subcinctus (Boheman, 1842); Hyperoides victus (Germain, 1896).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Host plants.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Hyperoides fragariae: Fragaria vesca L. (Rosaceae); Hyperoides subcinctus: Senecio sp. (Asteraceae); Hyperoides murinus: Citrulus vulgaris Schrad. (Cucurbitaceae), Phaseolus sp. (Fabaceae) and Solanum tuberosum L. (Solanaceae); Hyperoides victus: Senecio bahioides Hook. et Arn. (Asteraceae) (Morrone 1993b; Lanteri et al. 2002).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Geographical distribution.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Neotropical region and Andean region (Central Chilean subregion), in Argentina, Chile and Uruguay, and introduced into South Africa (Morrone 1993b).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Material examined.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Hyperoides balfourbrownei (MLP, MZFC), Hyperoides fragariae (BMNH, CBPC, MNHN), Hyperoides murinus (BMNH, CWOB, MHNS, MZFC), Hyperoides subcinctus (AMNH, BMNH, CBPC, CMNC, CWOB, IADIZA, MACN, MHNS, MNHN, MZFC) and Hyperoides victus (BMNH, CMNC, CWOB, MHNS).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Type species.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Lamiarhinus aelficus Morrone, 1992.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Diagnosis.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Small to medium-sized (5.7–6.8 mm); vestiture of seta-like scales and setae; funicular segments 3-6 elongate; pronotum with tubercles; elytra subrectangular, fused along interelytral suture.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Relationships.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Lamiarhinus is the sister genus to Philippius. In a previous analysis (Morrone 1997a), it was considered to be related to Trachodema.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Species included.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Lamiarhinus aelficus Morrone, 1992; Lamiarhinus horridus (Germain, 1896).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Host plants.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Lamiarhinus aelficus: Podanthus ovatifolius Lag. (Asteraceae) (Morrone 1992c).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Geographical distribution.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Andean region (Central Chilean subregion) (Morrone 1992c).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Material examined.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Lamiarhinus aelficus (CMNC, CWOB, MLP, MZFC) and Lamiarhinus horridus (MHNS).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Type species.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Listroderes costirostris Schönherr, 1826 (by original designation, combined description).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Diagnosis.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Small to medium-sized (3.9–12.5 mm); vestiture of subcircular scales and setae; scrobal ventral tooth usually present.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Relationships.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Listroderes is closely related to Antarctobius, Germainiellus and the clade Methypora-Rupanius-Acrorius-Trachodema-Lamiarhinus-Philippius. The distinction between Antarctobius, Germainiellus and Listroderes is not without doubt (see Morrone and Marvaldi 1998), and future analyses may determine if they are merged into a single genus.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Species included.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Listroderes affinis Hustache, 1926; Listroderes angusticeps Blanchard, 1851; Listroderes annulipes Blanchard, 1851; Listroderes apicalis Waterhouse, 1841; Listroderes bimaculatus Boheman, 1842; Listroderes brevirostris Germain, 1895; Listroderes brevisetis Hustache, 1926; Listroderes bruchi Hustache, 1926; Listroderes charybdis Morrone, 1993; Listroderes cinerarius Blanchard, 1851; Listroderes confusus Hustache, 1926; Listroderes costirostris Schönherr, 1826; Listroderes curvipes Germain, 1895; Listroderes delaiguei Germain, 1895; Listroderes desertorum Germain, 1895; Listroderes difficilis Germain, 1895; Listroderes elegans Hustache, 1926; Listroderes erinaceus Germain, 1895; Listroderes fallax Germain, 1895; Listroderes foveatus (Lea, 1928); Listroderes hoffmanni Germain, 1895; Listroderes howdenae Morrone, 1993; Listroderes leviculus Kuschel, 1952; Listroderes montanus Germain, 1895; Listroderes nodifer Boheman, 1842; Listroderes obliquus Klug, 1829; Listroderes obrieni Morrone, 1993; Listroderes paranensis Hustache, 1926; Listroderes punicola Kuschel, 1949; Listroderes pusillus Hustache, 1926; Listroderes robustior Schenkling and Marshall, 1931; Listroderes robustus Waterhouse, 1841; Listroderes scylla Morrone, 1993; Listroderes trivialis Germain, 1895; Listroderes tuberculifer Blanchard, 1851; Listroderes uruguayensis Kuschel, 1952; Listroderes wagneri Hustache, 1926; Listroderes wittei Hustache, 1926.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Host plants.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Listroderes apicalis: Betavulgaris L. (Chenopodiaceae), Helianthus annus L. (Asteraceae) and Triticum aestivum L. (Poaceae); Listroderes bimaculatus: Baccharis linearis (Ruiz and Pav.) Pers. (Asteraceae) and Puya chilensis Molina (Bromeliaceae); Listroderes bruchi: Baccharis salicifolia (Ruiz and Pavón) Pers. and Senecio subulatus Don Hooker et Arnott (Asteraceae); Listroderes cinerarius: Atriplex sp. (Chenopodiaceae); Listroderes costirostris, Listroderes difficilis and Listroderes obliquus: Apium graveolens L. and Daucus carota L. (Apiaceae), Brassica rapa L., Listroderes oleracea L. and Coronopus didymus (L.) Smith (Brassicaceae), Rumex altissimus Wood (Polygonaceae), Nicotiana tabacum L. and Solanum tuberosum L. (Solanaceae) and Stellaria spp. (Caryophyllaceae); Listroderes robustus: Atriplex semibaccata R. Br. (Chenopodiaceae); Listroderes uruguayensis: Hydrocotyle bonariensis Lam. (Apiaceae) (Morrone 1993d, 1995b; Marvaldi 1998; Lanteri et al. 2002).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Immature stages.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Listroderes bruchi, Listroderes delaiguei and Listroderes difficilis (May 1977, 1993, 1994; Marvaldi 1998).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Geographical distribution.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Andean region (Subantarctic, Central Chilean and Patagonian subregions), South American Transition Zone and Neotropical region, in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Paraguay, Peru and Uruguay, and introduced into Australia, Easter Island, Israel, Japan, New Zealand, South Africa, Spain and USA (Wibmer and O’Brien 1986; Kuschel 1990; Morrone 1993c-e, 1995b; Morrone 2002b; Friedman 2009; Posadas 2012).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Material examined.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Listroderes affinis (CBPC, IPCN, IPUM, MACN, MNHN), Listroderes angusticeps (MHNS, MNHN, MZFC), Listroderes annulipes (CBPC, CWOB, MHNS, MNHN, MZFC), Listroderes apicalis (AMNH, BMNH, CMNC, MACN, MHNS, MLP, MZFC), Listroderes bimaculatus (AMNH, BMNH, CMNC, CWOB, MACN, MHNS), Listroderes brevirostris (MHNS), Listroderes brevisetis (CBCP, DZUP, IPCN, MACN, MLP, MNHN), Listroderes bruchi (CMNC, DZUP, FIML, IADIZA, MACN, MLP, MZFC), Listroderes charybdis (MACN, MLP), Listroderes cinerarius (BMNH, CMNC, CWOB, IADIZA, MHNS, MNHN, MZFC), Listroderes confusus (DZUP, FIML, MACN, MLP, MNHN), Listroderes costirostris complex (AMNH, BMNH, CBPC, CMNC, CWOB, DZUP, FIML, GJWC, MACN, MHNS, MLP, MNHN, MZFC, MZSP, USNM), Listroderes curvipes (BMNH, CWOB, MHNS), Listroderes delaiguei (BMNH, CADIC, CWOB, IPUM, MHNS, MZFC), Listroderes desertorum (BMNH, CMNC, CWOB, MHNS, MZFC), Listroderes elegans (GJWC, MACN, MLP, MNHN), Listroderes erinaceus (MHNS), Listroderes fallax (CWOB, MHNS, MZFC), Listroderes foveatus (BMNH, CMNC, DZUP, FIML, GJWC, MACN, MZSP), Listroderes hoffmanni (BMNH, CWOB, MHNS, MZFC), Listroderes howdenae (CMNC, MLP, MZFC), Listroderes leviculus (BMNH), Listroderes montanus (MHNS, MZFC), Listroderes nodifer (BMNH, CWOB, MACN, MHNS), Listroderes obrieni (MHNS, MLP, MZFC), Listroderes paranensis (DZUP, MNHN), Listroderes punicola (CMNC, MHNS, MZFC), Listroderes pusillus (CBPC, MLP, MNHN, MZFC), Listroderes robustior (BMNH, CMNC, CWOB, MHNS, MLP, MZFC), Listroderes robustus (CMNC, CWOB, MHNS), Listroderes scylla (FIML, MLP), Listroderes trivialis (MHNS), Listroderes tuberculifer (CMNC, MHNS, MZFC), Listroderes uruguayensis (BMNH, CMNC), Listroderes wagneri (BMNH, MNHN) and Listroderes wittei (MACN, MNHN).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Type species.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Methypora postica Pascoe, 1865 (by indication, monotypy).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Diagnosis.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Small (4.0–7.0 mm); vestiture of subcircular scales and setae; pronotum subcylindrical, lacking tubercles; scutellum visible; elytra not fused along interelytral suture, lacking series of declivital tubercles; female elytral apex produced; tibiae with spurs.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Relationships.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Methypora is the sister genus to Rupanius.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Species included.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Methypora postica Pascoe, 1865 and Methypora tibialis Lea, 1911.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Geographical distribution.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Australia (Oberprieler 2010).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Material examined.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Methypora postica (BMNH).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Type species.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Listroderes superbus Reed, 1872 (subsequent designation by Wibmer and O’Brien 1986).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Diagnosis.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Large to very large (17.5–22.8 mm); vestiture of scales with finger-like processes and setae; mandible with 3-4 setae; pronotum wider than elytra; scutellum not visible; elytra subrectangular, fused along interelytral suture; tibiae lacking spurs; tarsomeres 3 subcylindrical.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Relationships.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Philippius is the sister genus to Lamiarhinus.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Species included.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Philippius superbus (Reed, 1872).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Geographical distribution.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Andean region (Subantarctic subregion), in southern Argentina and southern Chile (Kuschel 1987; Morrone 1990).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Material examined.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Philippius superbus (IADIZA, MACN, MHNS, MLP, USNM).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Type species.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Rupanius carinatus Morrone, 1995c.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Diagnosis.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Small (5.3–6.6 mm); vestiture of seta-like scales and setae; pronotum transverse; elytra subrectangular, with carina on apical declivity, disc slightly convex, lacking anteapical tubercle.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Relationships.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Rupanius is the sister genus to Methypora (Australia), and both are placed in Listroderina. In a previous analysis (Morrone 1997a) Rupanius was placed in the Macrostyphlus generic group (= Macrostyphlina).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Species included.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Rupanius carinatus Morrone, 1995.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Geographical distribution.
tp:treatment-sec.p: South American Transition Zone (North Andean Paramo biogeographical province), in Colombia (Morrone 1995c).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Material examined.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Rupanius carinatus (CMNC).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Type species.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Trachodema tuberculosa Blanchard, 1849 (by indication, monotypy).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Diagnosis.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Small to very small (2.5–5.3 mm); vestiture of scales with finger-like processes and setae; scape long (surpassing posterior margin of eye when resting in scrobe); pronotum transverse.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Relationships.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Trachodema is the sister genus to Lamiarhinus-Philippius.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Species included.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Trachodema paolae Alonso-Zarazaga, 2012 and Trachodema tuberculosa Blanchard, 1849.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Host plants.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Trachodema tuberculosa: Atriplex semibaccata R. Br. (Chenopodiaceae) (Morrone 1992c).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Geographical distribution.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Andean region (Central Chilean subregion) (Morrone 1992c).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Material examined.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Trachodema paolae (MHNS) and Trachodema tuberculosa (CMNC, CWOB, DZUP, FIML, MHNS, MZFC, USNM).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Distribution.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Ecuador and Peru (Wibmer and O’Brien 1986).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Distribution.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Chile (Wibmer and O’Brien 1986).

sec.title: Biogeographical Account
sec.p: The geographical distribution of the genera analysed indicates that Listroderini are basically a Gondwanan taxon, with Listronotus being the only genus distributed in North America. All the subtribes have Andean representatives (especially in the Subantarctic subregion), each showing a different pattern:
1 Macrostyphlina: exclusively Andean, in both the Andean region (Subantarctic and Central Chilean subregions) and the South American Transition Zone.
2 Falklandiina: distributed in the Andean region (Subantarctic subregion) and New Zealand.

3 Listroderina: distributed in the Andean region (Subantarctic, Patagonian and Central Chilean subregions), the South American and Mexican Transition Zones and the Neotropical and Australian Temperate regions.

4 Palaechthina: distributed in the Andean (Subantarctic and Central Chilean subregions), Neotropical and Nearctic regions, the South American Transition Zone, the Tristan da Cunha-Gough islands, New Zealand and the Australian Temperate region.

By replacing the genera for the areas where they are distributed, a taxon-area cladogram was obtained (Fig. 36). The paralogy-free subtrees that can be obtained from this taxon-area cladogram are mostly uninformative, and the informative ones cannot be combined into a general area cladogram. Geographical paralogy is particularly evident in the Subantarctic subregion, where representatives of the four subtribes are represented, suggesting that Listroderini are an ancient Gondwanan group. Several extinction events might have obscured the relationships among the areas.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: I thank Rolf Oberprieler for stimulating discussions on weevil systematics over the years and for donating specimens of Anorthorhinus, Samuel Brown for communicating some omissions and corrections to my 2011 checklist, Silvia Espinosa Matías for preparing the Scanning Electron Microscope images at the Facultad de Ciencias, UNAM, and Sergio Roig-Juñent for the habitus illustrations. Rolf Oberprieler and one anonymous reviewer provided very useful comments that helped improve the manuscript. The image of Gromilus veneris is used with permission of the Bishop Museum, Honolulu.
